ai-an3:59.6.1_0: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
ai-an3:59.6.2_0: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ ... ‘This is the origin of suffering’ ... ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
ai-an3:59.6.2_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
ai-an3:59.6.3_0: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ ... ‘This is the origin of defilements’ ... ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
ai-an3:59.6.4_0: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
ai-an3:59.6.5_0: When it is freed, he knows it is freed.
ai-an3:59.6.6_0: He understands: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
ai-an3:59.6.7_0: This is the third knowledge that they attain.
ai-an3:59.6.8_0: Ignorance was dispelled and knowledge arose.
ai-an3:59.6.8_1: darkness is destroyed and light has arisen, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
ai-an3:59.7.3_0: whose mind is immersed in samādhi,
ai-an3:59.8.2_0: seeing heaven and places of loss,
ai-an3:59.8.3_0: and have attained the end of rebirth;
ai-an3:59.9.2_0: that the brahmin is a master of the three knowledges.
ai-an3:59.9.3_0: I call a master of the three knowledges.
ai-an3:59.10.1_0: This, brahmin, is a master of the three knowledges in the training of the Noble One.”
ai-an3:59.10.2_0: “Master Gotama, the master of three knowledges according to the brahmins is quite different from a master of the three knowledges in the training of the Noble One.
ai-an3:59.10.3_0: And, Master Gotama, a master of three knowledges according to the brahmins is not worth a sixteenth part of a master of the three knowledges in the training of the Noble One.
ai-an3:59.11.2_0: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-an3:60.1.1_0: Then Saṅgārava the brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
ai-an3:60.1.2_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-an3:60.1.4_0: make sacrifices and encourage others to make sacrifices.
ai-an3:60.1.5_0: Now, Master Gotama, both of these people—the one who sacrifices and the one who encourages others to sacrifice—are doing good for many people on account of that sacrifice.
ai-an3:60.1.6_0: But, Master Gotama, if someone goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, they’re practicing one way in ten respects.”
ai-an3:60.2.1_0: “Well then, brahmin, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.
ai-an3:60.2.3_0: A Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
ai-an3:60.2.5_0: ‘Come, this is the path, this is the practice. Practicing like this, I realized the supreme culmination of the spiritual life with my own insight, and I make it known.
ai-an3:60.2.6_0: Please, all of you, practice like this, and you too will realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual life, and will live having realized it with your own insight.’
ai-an3:60.2.7_0: So they teach the Dhamma to that teacher. And so there are many hundreds in thousands of them.
ai-an3:60.3.2_0: This being so, are they doing good for just one person or for many people on account of going forth?”
ai-an3:60.3.3_0: “This being so, Master Gotama, they are doing good for many people on account of going forth.”
ai-an3:60.4.1_0: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to Saṅgārava,
ai-an3:60.4.2_0: “Brahmin, which of these two practices do you believe has fewer requirements and undertakings, yet is more fruitful and beneficial?”
ai-an3:60.4.4_0: “Those such as the masters Gotama and Ānanda
ai-an3:60.5.1_0: For a second time, Ānanda said to Saṅgārava,
ai-an3:60.5.4_0: In this way, brahmin, I ask you
ai-an3:60.5.5_0: which of these two practices do you believe has fewer requirements and undertakings, yet is more fruitful and beneficial?”
ai-an3:60.5.6_0: For a second time Saṅgārava said to Ānanda,
ai-an3:60.5.7_0: “Those such as the masters Gotama and Ānanda
ai-an3:60.6.1_0: For a third time, Ānanda said to Saṅgārava,
ai-an3:60.6.4_0: In this way, brahmin, I ask you
ai-an3:60.6.5_0: which of these two practices do you believe has fewer requirements and undertakings, yet is more fruitful and beneficial?”
ai-an3:60.6.6_0: For a third time Saṅgārava said to Ānanda,
ai-an3:60.6.7_0: “Those such as the masters Gotama and Ānanda
ai-an3:60.7.2_0: “Though Ānanda asked him a sensible question three times, Saṅgārava falters without answering.
ai-an3:60.7.4_0: So the Buddha said to Saṅgārava,
ai-an3:60.7.5_0: “Brahmin, what came up in the conversation among the king’s retinue today, sitting together in the royal compound?”
ai-an3:60.7.7_0: ‘Formerly, it seems, there were fewer mendicants, but more of them displayed superhuman demonstrations of psychic power;
ai-an3:60.7.8_0: But now these days there are more mendicants who are fewer superhuman demonstrations of psychic power, but will show them.’
ai-an3:60.7.9_0: This is what came up in the conversation among the king’s retinue today, while sitting together in the royal compound.”
ai-an3:60.8.1_0: “Brahmin, there are three kinds of demonstration.
ai-an3:60.8.3_0: The demonstration of psychic power, the demonstration of revealing, and the demonstration of instruction.
ai-an3:60.8.4_0: And what is the demonstration of psychic power?
ai-an3:60.8.5_0: It’s when someone wields the many kinds of psychic power:
ai-an3:60.8.5_1: even a bird who has been plenty of many.
ai-an3:60.8.5_3: Outside the walls, (wholes) go through the sky. It is like the sky.
ai-an3:60.8.5_4: They emerge from the earth and water, like the water in the sky.
ai-an3:60.8.5_5: As if they consum it into the water, it’s like the earth.
ai-an3:60.8.5_6: And the air that lumps the sky.
ai-an3:60.8.5_7: even the moon and sun, so mighty and powerful, controlling the body as far as the Brahmā realm.’
ai-an3:60.8.6_0: This is called the demonstration of psychic power.
ai-an3:60.9.1_0: And what is the demonstration of revealing?
ai-an3:60.9.2_0: Firstly, someone reveals by means of a sign,
ai-an3:60.9.3_0: ‘This is what you’re thinking, such is your thought, and thus is your state of mind.’
ai-an3:60.9.4_0: And even if they reveal this many times, it turns out exactly so, not otherwise.
ai-an3:60.10.1_0: In another case, someone reveals after hearing it from humans or non-humans or deities:
ai-an3:60.10.2_0: ‘This is what you’re thinking, such is your thought, and thus is your state of mind.’
ai-an3:60.10.3_0: And even if they reveal this many times, it turns out exactly so, not otherwise.
ai-an3:60.11.1_0: In another case, someone reveals by hearing the sound of thought spreading as someone thinks and considers:
ai-an3:60.11.2_0: ‘This is what you’re thinking, such is your thought, and thus is your state of mind.’
ai-an3:60.11.3_0: And even if they reveal this many times, it turns out exactly so, not otherwise.
ai-an3:60.12.1_0: In another case, someone comprehends the mind of a person who has attained the immersion that’s free of placing the mind and keeping it connected. They understand:
ai-an3:60.12.2_0: ‘Judging by the way this person’s intentions are directed, immediately after this mind state they’ll think this thought.’
ai-an3:60.12.3_0: And even if they reveal this many times, it turns out exactly so, not otherwise.
ai-an3:60.12.4_0: This is called the demonstration of revealing.
ai-an3:60.13.1_0: And what is a demonstration of instruction?
ai-an3:60.13.2_0: It’s when someone instructs others like this:
ai-an3:60.13.3_1: pay attention like this, not like this;
ai-an3:60.13.4_0: This is called a demonstration of instruction.
ai-an3:60.13.5_0: These are the three kinds of demonstration.
ai-an3:60.13.6_0: Of these three kinds of demonstration, which do you consider to be the finest?”
ai-an3:60.14.1_0: “Regarding this, Master Gotama, a demonstration of psychic power
ai-an3:60.14.2_0: Does he control the body as far as the world,
ai-an3:60.14.3_0: is experienced only by the one who performs it, occurring only to them.
ai-an3:60.14.4_0: This seems to me like a magic trick.
ai-an3:60.15.1_0: And the demonstration where someone reveals something by means of a sign,
ai-an3:60.15.3_0: or after hearing it from humans, non-humans, or deities,
ai-an3:60.15.4_0: or by hearing the sound of thought spreading as someone thinks and considers,
ai-an3:60.15.6_0: ‘Judging by the way this person’s intentions are directed, immediately after this mind state they’ll think it’s like that.’
ai-an3:60.15.7_0: is experienced only by the one who performs it, occurring only to them.
ai-an3:60.15.8_0: This also seems to me like a magic trick.
ai-an3:60.16.1_0: That, Master Gotama, this demonstration of instruction is this.
ai-an3:60.16.2_1: pay attention like this, not like this;
ai-an3:60.16.3_0: I prefer this demonstration, Master Gotama. It’s the finest of the three kinds of demonstration.
ai-an3:60.17.1_0: It’s incredible, Master Gotama, it’s amazing!
ai-an3:60.17.2_0: how well this was said by Master Gotama. We regard Master Gotama as someone who possesses these three kinds of demonstration.
ai-an3:60.17.3_0: For Master Gotama wields the many kinds of psychic power ... controlling the body as far as the Brahmā realm.
ai-an3:60.17.4_0: And Master Gotama comprehends the mind of another person who has attained the immersion that is free of placing the mind and keeping it connected. He understands:
ai-an3:60.17.5_0: ‘Judging by the way this person’s intentions are directed, immediately after this mind state they’ll think this thought.’
ai-an3:60.17.6_0: And Master Gotama instructs others like this:
ai-an3:60.17.7_1: pay attention like this, not like this;
ai-an3:60.18.1_0: “Your words are clearly invasive and intrusive, brahmin.
ai-an3:60.18.3_0: For I do wield the many kinds of psychic power ... controlling the body as far as the Brahmā realm.
ai-an3:60.18.4_0: And I do comprehend the mind of another person who has attained the immersion that is free of placing the mind and keeping it connected. I understand:
ai-an3:60.18.5_0: ‘Judging by the way this person’s intentions are directed, immediately after this mind state they’ll think this thought.’
ai-an3:60.18.6_0: For I teach them like this:
ai-an3:60.18.7_1: pay attention like this, not like this;
ai-an3:60.19.1_0: “But Master Gotama, is there even one other mendicant who possesses these three kinds of demonstration, apart from Master Gotama?”
ai-an3:60.19.2_0: “There’s not just one hundred mendicants, brahmin, who possess these three kinds of demonstration, nor two, three, four, or five hundred, but many more than that.”
ai-an3:60.19.3_0: “But where are these mendicants now staying?”
ai-an3:60.19.4_0: “Right here, brahmin, in this Saṅgha of mendicants.”
ai-an3:60.20.2_0: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what had been hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that
ai-an3:60.20.2_1: so that one with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-an3:60.20.2_2: just so has the Dhamma been explained by the dear Gotama in countless ways.
ai-an3:60.20.3_0: Good Gotama, I go for refuge to you, and to the Teaching and to the Sangha of monks.
ai-an3:60.20.4_0: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-an3:60.20.6_0: The first sub-chapter on lying down is finished.
ai-an3:60.21.3_0: looking down on the bank of the river,
ai-an3:61.1.1_0: “Mendicants, these three sectarian tenets—as pursued, pressed, and grilled by the astute—when taken to their conclusion, end with inaction.
ai-an3:61.1.3_0: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
ai-an3:61.1.4_0: ‘Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds.’
ai-an3:61.1.5_0: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
ai-an3:61.1.6_0: ‘Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of the Lord God’s creation.’
ai-an3:61.1.7_0: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
ai-an3:61.1.8_0: ‘Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—has no cause or reason.’
ai-an3:61.2.1_0: Here, monks, (as for) those ascetics and brahmins who are of this argument, this view:
ai-an3:61.2.2_0: everything that is experienced is because of past deeds, and I said to them:
ai-an3:61.2.3_0: ‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’
ai-an3:61.2.4_0: “Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds.”’
ai-an3:61.2.7_0: ‘In that case, you might kill living creatures, steal, be unchaste; use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; be covetous, malicious, or have wrong view, all because of past deeds.’
ai-an3:61.3.1_0: Those who believe that past deeds are the most important thing have no enthusiasm or effort, no idea that there are things that should and should not be done.
ai-an3:61.3.2_0: Since they don’t acknowledge as a genuine fact that there are things that should and should not be done, they’re unmindful and careless, and can’t rightly be called ascetics.
ai-an3:61.3.3_0: This is my first legitimate refutation of the ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view.
ai-an3:61.4.1_0: Here, monks, (as for) those ascetics and brahmins who are of this argument, this view:
ai-an3:61.4.2_0: everything that is experienced is because of the Lord God’s creation, and I said to them:
ai-an3:61.4.3_0: ‘Is it true that this is the venerables’ view?’
ai-an3:61.4.4_0: everything that is experienced is because of the Lord God’s creation, painful, or neutral—is because of the Lord God’s creation.’
ai-an3:61.4.7_0: ‘In that case, you might kill living creatures, steal, be unchaste; use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; be covetous, malicious, or have wrong view, all because of the Lord God’s creation.’
ai-an3:61.5.1_0: But, monks, for he who holds the power of God as the essential or transmigration, that there are things that should and should not be done.
ai-an3:61.5.2_0: Since they don’t acknowledge as a genuine fact that there are things that should and should not be done, they’re unmindful and careless, and can’t rightly be called ascetics.
ai-an3:61.5.3_0: This is my second legitimate refutation of the ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view.
ai-an3:61.6.1_0: Here, monks, (as for) those ascetics and brahmins who are of this argument, this view:
ai-an3:61.6.2_0: everything that is experienced has no cause or reason, and I said to them:
ai-an3:61.6.3_0: ‘Is it true that this is the venerables’ view?’
ai-an3:61.6.4_0: everything that is experienced has no cause or reason.’
ai-an3:61.6.7_0: ‘In that case, you might kill living creatures, steal, be unchaste; use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; be covetous, malicious, or have wrong view, all without cause or reason.’
ai-an3:61.6.7_1: they will hold to wrong views with no cause or condition.’”
ai-an3:61.7.1_0: Those who believe that the absence of cause or reason is the most important thing have no enthusiasm, no effort, no idea that there are things that should and should not be done.
ai-an3:61.7.2_0: Since they don’t acknowledge as a genuine fact that there are things that should and should not be done, they’re unmindful and careless, and can’t rightly be called ascetics.
ai-an3:61.7.3_0: This is my third legitimate refutation of the ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view.
ai-an3:61.8.1_0: These are the three sectarian tenets—as pursued, pressed, and grilled by the astute—which, when taken to their conclusion, end with inaction.
ai-an3:61.9.1_0: But this teaching is the Dhamma I’ve taught ...
ai-an3:61.9.2_0: What is the Dhamma that I’ve taught?
ai-an3:61.9.3_0: ‘These are the six elements’: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught ...
ai-an3:61.9.4_0: ‘These are the six fields of contact’: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught ...
ai-an3:61.9.5_0: ‘These are the eighteen mental preoccupations’: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught ...
ai-an3:61.9.6_0: ‘These are the four noble truths’: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught that is irrefutable, uncorrupted, beyond reproach, and is not scorned by sensible ascetics and brahmins.
ai-an3:61.10.1_0: ‘These are the six elements’: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught ...
ai-an3:61.10.3_0: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
ai-an3:61.10.5_0: earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness.
ai-an3:61.10.6_0: ‘These are the six elements’: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught ...
ai-an3:61.10.7_0: That’s why I said what I said.
ai-an3:61.11.1_0: ‘These are the six fields of contact’: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught ...
ai-an3:61.11.3_0: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
ai-an3:61.11.4_0: There are these six fields of contact:
ai-an3:61.11.5_0: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind contact.
ai-an3:61.11.6_0: ‘These are the six fields of contact’: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught ...
ai-an3:61.11.7_0: That’s why I said what I said.
ai-an3:61.12.1_0: ‘These are the eighteen mental preoccupations’: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught ...
ai-an3:61.12.3_0: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
ai-an3:61.12.4_0: Seeing a sight with the eye, one is preoccupied with a sight that’s a basis for happiness or sadness or equanimity.
ai-an3:61.12.5_0: When you hear a sound with your ears ...
ai-an3:61.12.6_0: When they smell an odor with their nose ...
ai-an3:61.12.7_0: Tasting a flavor with the tongue ...
ai-an3:61.12.8_0: Feeling a touch with the body ...
ai-an3:61.12.9_0: Becoming conscious of a thought with the mind, one is preoccupied with a thought that’s a basis for happiness or sadness or equanimity.
ai-an3:61.12.10_0: ‘These are the eighteen mental preoccupations’: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught ...
ai-an3:61.12.11_0: That’s why I said what I said.
ai-an3:61.13.1_0: ‘“These are the four noble truths”: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught ...’
ai-an3:61.13.3_0: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
ai-an3:61.13.4_0: Supported by the six elements, an embryo is conceived.
ai-an3:61.13.5_0: When it is conceived, there are name and form. Name and form are conditions for the six sense fields. The six sense fields are conditions for contact. Contact is a condition for feeling.
ai-an3:61.13.6_0: It’s for one who feels that I declare: ‘This is suffering’ ... ‘This is the origin of suffering’ ... ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
ai-an3:61.14.1_0: And what is the noble truth of suffering?
ai-an3:61.14.2_0: Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are suffering; association with the disliked is suffering; separation from the liked is suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering.
ai-an3:61.14.2_1: in brief, the five components (of mind and body) that provide fuel for attachment are suffering.
ai-an3:61.14.3_0: This I say, monks, is the noble truth of suffering.
ai-an3:61.15.1_0: And what is the noble truth of the origin of suffering?
ai-an3:61.15.2_0: ignorance is a condition for choices.
ai-an3:61.15.3_0: with a (volitional) process as condition: consciousness,
ai-an3:61.15.4_0: with consciousness as condition: mind and bodily form,
ai-an3:61.15.5_0: because of mind and body: the six sense spheres,
ai-an3:61.15.6_0: because of the six sense spheres: contact,
ai-an3:61.15.12_0: with birth as condition: old age, death, grief, lamentation, pain, sorrow, and despair (all) arise,
ai-an3:61.15.13_0: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
ai-an3:61.15.14_0: This I say, monks, is the noble truth of the arising of suffering.
ai-an3:61.16.1_0: And what is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering?
ai-an3:61.16.2_0: But from the complete fading away and cessation of ignorance, there is the cessation of volitions,
ai-an3:61.16.3_0: from the cessation of (volitional) processes, the cessation of consciousness,
ai-an3:61.16.4_0: from the cessation of consciousness, the cessation of mind and bodily form,
ai-an3:61.16.5_0: from the cessation of mind and bodily form, the cessation of the six sense spheres,
ai-an3:61.16.6_0: from the cessation of the six sense spheres, the cessation of contact,
ai-an3:61.16.8_0: from the cessation of feeling, the cessation of craving,
ai-an3:61.16.9_0: from the cessation of craving, the cessation of attachment,
ai-an3:61.16.10_0: with the cessation of attachment, the cessation of continuation,
ai-an3:61.16.11_0: from the cessation of continuation, the cessation of birth,
ai-an3:61.16.12_0: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.
ai-an3:61.16.13_0: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’
ai-an3:61.16.14_0: This I say, monks, is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.
ai-an3:61.17.1_0: Now what, monks, is the Noble Truth of the Practice Leading to the Cessation of Suffering?
ai-an3:61.17.3_0: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
ai-an3:61.17.4_0: This, monks, is called the Noble Truth of the Practice Leading to the Cessation of Suffering.
ai-an3:61.17.5_0: ‘“These are the four noble truths”: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught that is irrefutable, uncorrupted, beyond reproach, and is not scorned by sensible ascetics and brahmins.’
ai-an3:61.17.6_0: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.”
ai-an3:62.1.1_0: “Mendicants, an uneducated ordinary person speaks of three perils that tear mothers and children apart.
ai-an3:62.1.3_0: There comes a time when a great fire flares up,
ai-an3:62.1.4_0: and it burns villages, towns, and cities.
ai-an3:62.1.5_0: When this happens, sometimes a mother can’t find her child, and a child can’t find their mother.
ai-an3:62.1.6_0: This is the first peril that tears mothers and children apart.
ai-an3:62.2.1_0: Furthermore, there comes a time when a great storm gathers,
ai-an3:62.2.2_0: and it unleashes a mighty flood
ai-an3:62.2.3_0: that sweeps away villages, towns, and cities.
ai-an3:62.2.4_0: When this happens, sometimes a mother can’t find her child, and a child can’t find their mother.
ai-an3:62.2.5_0: This is the second peril that tears mothers and children apart.
ai-an3:62.3.1_0: Furthermore, there comes a time of peril from wild savages, and the countryfolk mount their vehicles and flee everywhere.
ai-an3:62.3.2_0: When this happens, a mother can’t find her child, and a child can’t find their mother.
ai-an3:62.3.3_0: This is the third peril that tears mothers and children apart.
ai-an3:62.3.4_0: These are the three perils an uneducated ordinary person speaks of that tear mothers and children apart.
ai-an3:62.4.1_0: There are these three perils an uneducated ordinary person speaks of that don’t tear mothers and children apart.
ai-an3:62.4.3_0: There comes a time when a great fire flares up,
ai-an3:62.4.4_0: and it burns villages, towns, and cities.
ai-an3:62.4.5_0: When this happens, sometimes a mother can find her child, and a child can find their mother.
ai-an3:62.4.6_0: This is the first peril that doesn’t tear mothers and children apart.
ai-an3:62.5.1_0: Furthermore, there comes a time when a great storm gathers,
ai-an3:62.5.2_0: and it unleashes a mighty flood
ai-an3:62.5.3_0: that sweeps away villages, towns, and cities.
ai-an3:62.5.4_0: When this happens, sometimes a mother can find her child, and a child can find their mother.
ai-an3:62.5.5_0: This is the second peril that doesn’t tear mothers and children apart.
ai-an3:62.6.1_0: Furthermore, there comes a time of peril from wild savages, and the countryfolk mount their vehicles and flee everywhere.
ai-an3:62.6.2_0: When this happens, sometimes a mother can find her child, and a child can find their mother.
ai-an3:62.6.3_0: This is the third peril that doesn’t tear mothers and children apart.
ai-an3:62.6.4_0: These are the three perils an uneducated ordinary person speaks of that don’t tear mothers and children apart.
ai-an3:62.7.1_0: There are three perils that tear mothers and children apart.
ai-an3:62.7.3_0: The perils of old age, sickness, and death.
ai-an3:62.7.4_0: When a child is growing old, a mother doesn’t get her wish:
ai-an3:62.7.5_0: ‘Let me grow old, may my child not grow old!’
ai-an3:62.7.6_0: When a mother is growing old, a child doesn’t get their wish:
ai-an3:62.7.7_0: ‘Let me grow old, may my mother not grow old!’
ai-an3:62.8.1_0: When a mother is sick, a child doesn’t get sick,
ai-an3:62.8.2_0: ‘Let me be sick, may my child not be sick!’
ai-an3:62.8.3_0: When a mother is dying, a child doesn’t get sick,
ai-an3:62.8.4_0: ‘Let me be sick, may my mother not be sick!’
ai-an3:62.9.1_0: When a mother is dying, a child doesn’t get their wish:
ai-an3:62.9.2_0: ‘Let me die, may my child not die!’
ai-an3:62.9.3_0: When a mother is dying, a child doesn’t get their wish:
ai-an3:62.9.4_0: ‘Let me die, may my mother not die!’
ai-an3:62.9.5_0: These are the three perils that tear mothers and children apart.
ai-an3:62.10.1_0: There is a path and a practice that leads to giving up and going beyond the three perils that don’t tear mothers and children apart, and the three perils that do tear mothers and children apart.
ai-an3:62.10.2_0: What is that path and practice?
ai-an3:62.10.4_0: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
ai-an3:62.10.5_0: This is the path, this is the practice that leads to giving up and going beyond the three perils that don’t tear mothers and children apart, and the three perils that do tear mothers and children apart.”
ai-an3:63.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Venāgapura.
ai-an3:63.1.2_0: The brahmins and householders of Venāgapura heard:
ai-an3:63.1.3_0: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Venāgapura.
ai-an3:63.1.5_0: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
ai-an3:63.1.6_0: He realizes with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
ai-an3:63.1.7_0: He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
ai-an3:63.1.8_0: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
ai-an3:63.2.1_0: Then the brahmins and householders of Venāgapura went up to the Buddha.
ai-an3:63.2.1_1: Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.
ai-an3:63.2.1_2: Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent. Then the brahmin Vacchagotta of Venāgapura said to the Buddha:
ai-an3:63.3.1_0: He said, “It’s incredible, Master Gotama, it’s amazing!
ai-an3:63.3.2_0: how your faculties are so very clear, and the complexion of your skin is pure and bright.
ai-an3:63.3.3_0: It’s like a golden brown jujube in the autumn,
ai-an3:63.3.4_0: In the same way, your faculties are so very clear, and the complexion of your skin is pure and bright.
ai-an3:63.3.5_0: or a palm fruit freshly plucked from the stalk,
ai-an3:63.3.6_0: In the same way, your faculties are so very clear, and the complexion of your skin is pure and bright.
ai-an3:63.3.7_0: or a pendant of river gold, fashioned by a deft smith, well wrought in the forge, and placed on a cream rug where it shines and glows and radiates.
ai-an3:63.3.8_0: In the same way, your faculties are so very clear, and the complexion of your skin is pure and bright.
ai-an3:63.3.9_0: Surely Master Gotama gets when he wants, without trouble or difficulty, various kinds of high and luxurious bedding, such as:
ai-an3:63.3.10_0: sofas, couches, woolen covers—shag-piled, colorful, white, embroidered with flowers, quilted, embroidered with animals, double-or single-fringed—and silk covers studded with gems, as well as silken sheets, woven carpets, rugs for elephants, horses, or chariots, antelope hide rugs, and spreads of fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red cushions at both ends.”
ai-an3:63.4.1_0: “Brahmin, these various kinds of high and luxurious bedding
ai-an3:63.4.2_0: a high couch, a luxurious couch, a long-fleeced woolen rug, a multi-colored woolen rug, a white woolen rug, a red woolen rug, a cotton-down quilt, a woolen rug decorated with the images of predatory animals, a woolen rug with long flece on one side, a woolen rug with long flece on both sides, a sheet of silk embroidered with gems, a silken sheet, a woolen rug like a dancers’ rug, an elephant-back rug, a horse-back rug, a carriage-seat rug, a rug made of black antelope hide, an excellent sheet made of _kadalī_-deer hide, a seat with a canopy,
ai-an3:63.4.3_0: are hard for renunciates to find. And even if they do get them, they’re not allowed.
ai-an3:63.5.1_0: These are the three high and luxurious beds that I get these days when I want, without trouble or difficulty.
ai-an3:63.5.3_0: The high and luxurious beds of the gods, of Brahmā, and of the noble ones.
ai-an3:63.5.4_0: These are the three high and luxurious beds that I get these days when I want, without trouble or difficulty.”
ai-an3:63.6.1_0: “But what, Master Gotama, is the high and luxurious bed of the gods?”
ai-an3:63.6.2_0: “Brahmin, when I am living supported by a village or town, I robe up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, enter the town or village for alms.
ai-an3:63.6.3_0: After the meal, on my return from alms-round, I enter a wood.
ai-an3:63.6.4_0: I gather up some grass or leaves into a pile, and sit down cross-legged, with my body straight, and establish mindfulness right there.
ai-an3:63.6.5_0: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-an3:63.6.7_0: And with the fading away of rapture, I meditate equanimous, mindful, and aware, experiencing bliss directly, and I entered and remained in the third absorption of which the noble ones declare:
ai-an3:63.6.7_1: ‘One is even-minded, mindful, and abides in bliss.’
ai-an3:63.6.8_0: With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
ai-an3:63.6.9_0: When I’m practicing like this, if I walk, at that time I walk like the gods.
ai-an3:63.6.10_0: When I’m practicing like this, if I stand, at that time I stand like the gods.
ai-an3:63.6.11_0: When I’m practicing like this, if I sit, at that time I sit like the gods.
ai-an3:63.6.12_0: When I’m practicing like this, if I lie down, at that time I lie down like the gods.
ai-an3:63.6.13_0: This is the high and luxurious bed of the gods that I get these days when I want, without trouble or difficulty.”
ai-an3:63.7.1_0: He said, “It’s incredible, Master Gotama, it’s amazing!
ai-an3:63.7.2_0: Who but Master Gotama could get such a high and luxurious bed of the gods when he wants, without trouble or difficulty?
ai-an3:63.8.1_0: But what, Master Gotama, is the high and luxurious bed of Brahmā?”
ai-an3:63.8.2_0: “Brahmin, when I am living supported by a village or town, I robe up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, enter the town or village for alms.
ai-an3:63.8.3_0: After the meal, on my return from alms-round, I enter a wood.
ai-an3:63.8.4_0: I gather up some grass or leaves into a pile, and sit down cross-legged, with my body straight, and establish mindfulness right there.
ai-an3:63.8.5_0: I meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, I spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
ai-an3:63.8.9_0: When I’m practicing like this, if I walk, at that time I walk like Brahmā.
ai-an3:63.8.10_0: ... I stand like the noble ones ...
ai-an3:63.8.12_0: at that time I lie down when my supreme penalty is luxurious.
ai-an3:63.8.13_0: This is the high and luxurious bed of Brahmā that I get these days when I want, without trouble or difficulty.”
ai-an3:63.9.1_0: He said, “It’s incredible, Master Gotama, it’s amazing!
ai-an3:63.9.2_0: Who but Master Gotama could get such a high and luxurious bed of Brahmā when he wants, without trouble or difficulty?
ai-an3:63.10.1_0: But what, Master Gotama, is the high and luxurious bed of the noble ones?”
ai-an3:63.10.2_0: “Brahmin, when I am living supported by a village or town, I robe up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, enter the town or village for alms.
ai-an3:63.10.3_0: After the meal, on my return from alms-round, I enter a wood.
ai-an3:63.10.4_0: I gather up some grass or leaves into a pile, and sit down cross-legged, with my body straight, and establish mindfulness right there.
ai-an3:63.10.6_0: ‘I’ve given up greed, hate, and delusion, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so they’re unable to arise in the future.’
ai-an3:63.10.7_0: I’ve given up hate, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
ai-an3:63.10.8_0: I’ve given up delusion, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so they’re unable to arise in the future.’
ai-an3:63.10.9_0: When I’m practicing like this, if I walk, at that time I walk like the noble ones.
ai-an3:63.10.10_0: ... I stand like the noble ones ...
ai-an3:63.10.12_0: at that time I lie down in my bedroom in a noble disciple.
ai-an3:63.10.13_0: This is the high and luxurious bed of the noble ones that I get these days when I want, without trouble or difficulty.”
ai-an3:63.11.1_0: He said, “It’s incredible, Master Gotama, it’s amazing!
ai-an3:63.11.2_0: Who but Master Gotama could get such a high and luxurious bed of the noble ones when he wants, without trouble or difficulty?
ai-an3:63.12.2_0: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what had been hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that
ai-an3:63.12.2_1: so that one with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-an3:63.12.2_2: just so has the Dhamma been explained by the dear Gotama in countless ways.
ai-an3:63.12.3_0: We go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
ai-an3:63.12.4_0: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”
ai-an3:64.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
ai-an3:64.1.3_0: Now at that time a wanderer called Sarabha had recently left this teaching and training.
ai-an3:64.1.4_0: He was telling a crowd in Rājagaha:
ai-an3:64.1.5_0: “I learned the teaching of the ascetics who follow the Sakyan,
ai-an3:64.1.6_0: then I left their teaching and training.”
ai-an3:64.1.7_0: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Rājagaha for alms.
ai-an3:64.1.8_0: They heard what Sarabha was saying.
ai-an3:64.1.9_0: “I learned the teaching of the ascetics who follow the Sakyan,
ai-an3:64.1.10_0: then I left their teaching and training.”
ai-an3:64.2.1_0: Then, after the meal, when they returned from alms-round, they went up to the Buddha,
ai-an3:64.2.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-an3:64.2.2_0: “Sir, the wanderer named Abhibhū left this teaching and training.
ai-an3:64.2.3_0: He was telling a crowd in Rājagaha:
ai-an3:64.2.4_0: ‘I learned the teaching of the ascetics who follow the Sakyan,
ai-an3:64.2.5_0: then I left their teaching and training.’
ai-an3:64.2.6_0: Sir, please go to the wanderers’ monastery on the banks of the Sappinī river to see Sarabha the wanderer out of compassion.”
ai-an3:64.2.7_0: The Buddha consented by remaining silent.
ai-an3:64.3.1_0: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the wanderer’s monastery on the bank of the Sappinī river.
ai-an3:64.3.1_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-an3:64.3.1_2: He sat on the seat spread out, and said to the wanderer Sarabha,
ai-an3:64.3.2_0: “Is it really true, Sarabha, that you said this:
ai-an3:64.3.3_0: ‘I learned the teaching of the ascetics who follow the Sakyan,
ai-an3:64.3.4_0: then I left their teaching and training.’”
ai-an3:64.3.5_0: When he said this, Sarabha kept silent.
ai-an3:64.4.1_0: For a second time, the Buddha said,
ai-an3:64.4.2_0: “Tell me, Sarabha, what exactly have you learned of the teachings of the ascetics who follow the Sakyan?
ai-an3:64.4.3_0: If you’ve not learned it fully, I’ll fill you in.
ai-an3:64.4.4_0: But if you have learned it fully, I’ll agree.”
ai-an3:64.4.5_0: For a second time, Sarabha kept silent.
ai-an3:64.5.1_0: For a third time, the Buddha said to Sarabha,
ai-an3:64.5.2_0: “Sarabha, the teachings of the ascetics who follow the Sakyan are clear to me. What exactly have you learned of the teachings of the ascetics who follow the Sakyan?
ai-an3:64.5.3_0: If you’ve not learned it fully, I’ll fill you in.
ai-an3:64.5.4_0: But if you have learned it fully, I’ll agree.”
ai-an3:64.5.5_0: For a third time, Sarabha kept silent.
ai-an3:64.6.1_0: Then those wanderers said to Sarabha,
ai-an3:64.6.2_0: “The ascetic Gotama has offered to tell you anything you ask for.
ai-an3:64.6.3_0: Speak, reverend Sarabha, what exactly have you learned of the teachings of the ascetics who follow the Sakyan?
ai-an3:64.6.4_0: If you’ve not learned it fully, he’ll fill you in.
ai-an3:64.6.5_0: But if you have learned it fully, he’ll agree.”
ai-an3:64.6.6_0: When this was said, Sarabha sat silent, embarrassed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.
ai-an3:64.7.1_0: Knowing this, the Buddha said to the wanderers:
ai-an3:64.8.2_0: ‘You claim to be a fully awakened Buddha, but regarding these things you’re not fully awakened.’ Then I’d carefully pursue, press, and grill them on that point.
ai-an3:64.8.3_0: When grilled by me, they would, without a doubt, fall into one of these three categories. They’d dodge the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points. They’d display annoyance, hate, and bitterness. Or they’d sit silent, embarrassed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say, like Sarabha.
ai-an3:64.9.1_0: Wanderers, someone might say to me:
ai-an3:64.9.2_0: ‘You claim to be one who has ended the defilements.’ Then I’d carefully pursue, press, and grill them on that point.
ai-an3:64.9.3_0: When grilled by me, they would, without a doubt, fall into one of these three categories. They’d dodge the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points. They’d display annoyance, hate, and bitterness. Or they’d sit silent, embarrassed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say, like Sarabha.
ai-an3:64.10.1_0: Wanderers, someone might say to me:
ai-an3:64.10.2_0: ‘Your teaching does not lead someone who practices it to the goal of the complete ending of suffering.’ Then I’d carefully pursue, press, and grill them on that point.
ai-an3:64.10.3_0: When grilled by me, they would, without a doubt, fall into one of these three categories. They’d dodge the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points. They’d display annoyance, hate, and bitterness. Or they’d sit silent, embarrassed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say, like Sarabha.”
ai-an3:64.10.4_0: Then the Buddha, having roared his lion’s roar three times in the wanderers’ monastery on the bank of the Sappinī river, rose into the sky and flew away.
ai-an3:64.11.1_0: Soon after the Buddha left, those wanderers gave Sañjaya back to the wanderer Sarabha.
ai-an3:64.11.2_0: “Reverend Sarabha, you’re just like an old jackal in the formidable wilderness who thinks, ‘I’ll roar a lion’s roar!’ but they still only manage to squeal and yelp like a jackal.
ai-an3:64.11.3_0: In the same way, when the ascetic Gotama wasn’t here you said ‘I’ll roar a lion’s roar!’ but you only managed to squeal and yelp like a jackal.
ai-an3:64.11.4_0: You’re just like a golden oriole who thinks, ‘I’ll cry like a cuckoo!’ but they still only manage to cry like a golden oriole.
ai-an3:64.11.5_0: In the same way, when the ascetic Gotama wasn’t here you said ‘I’ll cry like a cuckoo!’ but you still only managed to cry like a golden oriole.
ai-an3:64.11.6_0: Suppose there was a bull with its territory. The cowherd thinks he’d identify with deep wisdom.
ai-an3:64.11.7_0: In the same way, you only thought to bellow when the ascetic Gotama wasn’t here.”
ai-an3:64.11.8_0: Then those wanderers together with Sarabha,
ai-an3:65.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a town of the Kālāmas named Kesamutta.
ai-an3:65.1.4_0: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Keakula.
ai-an3:65.1.6_0: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha ...’
ai-an3:65.1.7_0: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
ai-an3:65.2.1_0: Then Kālāmas went to the Fortunate One,
ai-an3:65.2.1_1: Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.
ai-an3:65.2.1_2: Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent. Seated to one side the Kālāmas said to the Buddha:
ai-an3:65.3.1_0: “There are, sir, some ascetics and brahmins who come to Kesamutta.
ai-an3:65.3.2_0: They explain and promote only their own doctrine, while they attack, badmouth, disparage, and smear the doctrines of others.
ai-an3:65.3.3_0: Then some other ascetics and brahmins come to Kesamutta.
ai-an3:65.3.4_0: They too explain and promote only their own doctrine, while they attack, badmouth, disparage, and smear the doctrines of others.
ai-an3:65.3.5_0: So, sir, we’re doubting and uncertain:
ai-an3:65.3.6_0: ‘I wonder who of these respected ascetics and brahmins speaks the truth, and who speaks falsehood?’”
ai-an3:65.3.7_0: “It is enough, Kālāmas, for you to be doubting and uncertain.
ai-an3:65.3.8_0: Doubt has come up in you about an uncertain matter.
ai-an3:65.4.1_0: Please, Kālāmas, don’t go by oral transmission, don’t go by lineage, don’t go by testament, don’t go by canonical authority, don’t rely on logic, don’t rely on inference, don’t go by reasoned contemplation, don’t go by the acceptance of a view after consideration, don’t go by the appearance of competence, and don’t think ‘The ascetic is our respected teacher.’
ai-an3:65.4.2_0: But when you know for yourselves:
ai-an3:65.4.3_0: ‘These things are unskillful, blameworthy, criticized by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to harm and suffering’, then you should give them up.
ai-an3:65.5.2_0: Does greed come up in a person for their welfare or harm?”
ai-an3:65.7.1_0: “A greedy individual—overcome by greed—kills living creatures, steals, commits adultery, lies, and encourages others to do the same. Is that for their lasting harm and suffering?”
ai-an3:65.9.2_0: Does hate come up in a person for their welfare or harm?”
ai-an3:65.11.1_0: “A hateful individual, overcome by hate, kills living creatures, steals, commits adultery, lies, and encourages others to do the same. Is that for their lasting harm and suffering?”
ai-an3:65.13.2_0: Does delusion come up in a person for their welfare or harm?”
ai-an3:65.15.1_0: “A deluded individual, overcome by delusion, kills living creatures, steals, commits adultery, lies, and encourages others to do the same. Is that for their lasting harm and suffering?”
ai-an3:65.17.1_0: “What do you think, Kālāmas, are these things skillful or unskillful?”
ai-an3:65.21.1_0: “Dears in full awareness, disagreeable or unshakable?”
ai-an3:65.23.1_0: “When you undertake them, do they lead to harm and suffering, or not?
ai-an3:65.23.2_0: Or how do you see this?”
ai-an3:65.24.1_0: “When you undertake them, they lead to harm and suffering.
ai-an3:65.25.3_0: don’t go by oral transmission, don’t go by lineage, don’t go by testament, don’t go by canonical authority, don’t rely on logic, don’t rely on inference, don’t go by reasoned contemplation, don’t go by the acceptance of a view after consideration, don’t go by the appearance of competence, and don’t think “The ascetic is our respected teacher.”
ai-an3:65.25.4_0: But when you know for yourselves:
ai-an3:65.25.5_0: “These things are unskillful, blameworthy, criticized by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to harm and suffering”, then you should give them up.’
ai-an3:65.25.6_0: That’s why I said what I said.
ai-an3:65.26.1_0: Please, Kālāmas, don’t go by oral transmission, don’t go by lineage, don’t go by testament, don’t go by canonical authority, don’t rely on logic, don’t rely on inference, don’t go by reasoned contemplation, don’t go by the acceptance of a view after consideration, don’t go by the appearance of competence, and don’t think ‘The ascetic is our respected teacher.’
ai-an3:65.26.2_0: But when you know for yourselves:
ai-an3:65.26.3_0: ‘These things are skillful, blameless, praised by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to welfare and happiness’, then you should acquire them and keep them.
ai-an3:65.27.2_0: Does contentment ... love ... understanding ... benevolence come up in a person for their welfare or harm?”
ai-an3:65.29.1_0: “An individual who is content, not overcome by greed, doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit adultery, lie, or encourage others to do the same. Is that for their lasting welfare and happiness?”
ai-an3:65.31.4_0: Is that for their lasting welfare and happiness?”
ai-an3:65.33.1_0: “What do you think, Kālāmas, are these things skillful or unskillful?”
ai-an3:65.37.1_0: “Dears in full awareness, disagreeable or unshakable?”
ai-an3:65.39.1_0: “When you undertake them, do they lead to welfare and happiness, or not?
ai-an3:65.39.2_0: Or how do you see this?”
ai-an3:65.40.1_0: “When you undertake them, they lead to welfare and happiness.

ai-an3:65.41.4_0: But when you know for yourselves:

ai-an3:66.1.2_0: Now at that time Venerable Nandaka was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.
ai-an3:66.1.3_0: Then Sāḷha, Migāra’s grandson, and Rohaṇa, Pekhuṇiya’s grandson went up to Venerable Nandaka.
ai-an3:66.1.3_1: They bowed, and sat down to one side.
ai-an3:66.1.3_2: Then Venerable Nandaka said to Sāḷha:
ai-an3:66.2.1_0: “Please, Sāḷha and friend, don’t go by oral transmission, don’t go by lineage, don’t go by testament, don’t go by canonical authority, don’t rely on logic, don’t rely on inference, don’t go by reasoned contemplation, don’t go by the acceptance of a view after consideration, don’t go by the appearance of competence, and don’t think ‘The ascetic is our respected teacher.’
ai-an3:66.2.2_0: But when you know for yourselves: ‘These things are unskillful, blameworthy, criticized by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to harm and suffering’, then you should give them up.
ai-an3:66.5.1_0: “‘Covetousness’ is what I mean by this.
ai-an3:66.5.2_0: A person who is greedy and covetous kills living creatures, steals, commits adultery, lies, and encourages others to do the same. Is that for their lasting harm and suffering?”
ai-an3:66.9.1_0: “‘Malice’ is what I mean by this.
ai-an3:66.9.2_0: A hateful and malicious person kills living creatures, steals, commits adultery, lies, and encourages others to do the same. Is that for their lasting harm and suffering?”
ai-an3:66.13.1_0: “‘Knowledge’ is what I mean by this.
ai-an3:66.13.2_0: A person who is deluded and ignorant kills living creatures, steals, commits adultery, lies, and encourages others to do the same. Is that for their lasting harm and suffering?”
ai-an3:66.15.1_0: “What do you think, Sāḷha, are these things skillful or unskillful?”
ai-an3:66.19.1_0: “Dears in full awareness, disagreeable or unshakable?”
ai-an3:66.21.1_0: “When you undertake them, do they lead to harm and suffering, or not?
ai-an3:66.21.2_0: Or how do you see this?”
ai-an3:66.22.1_0: “When you undertake them, they lead to harm and suffering.
ai-an3:66.23.1_0: “So, Sāḷha and friend, when I said:
ai-an3:66.23.2_0: ‘Please, Sāḷha and friend, don’t go by oral transmission, don’t go by lineage, don’t go by testament, don’t go by canonical authority, don’t rely on logic, don’t rely on inference, don’t go by reasoned contemplation, don’t go by the acceptance of a view after consideration, don’t go by the appearance of competence, and don’t think ‘The ascetic is our respected teacher.’

ai-an3:66.23.4_0: “These things are unskillful, blameworthy, criticized by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to harm and suffering”, then you should give them up.’
ai-an3:66.23.5_0: That’s why I said what I said.

ai-an3:66.24.3_0: ‘These things are skillful, blameless, praised by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to welfare and happiness’, then you should acquire them and keep them.
ai-an3:66.25.1_0: What do you think? Is love real?”

ai-an3:66.27.2_0: A person who is content and satisfied doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit adultery, lie, or encourage others to do the same. Is that for their lasting welfare and happiness?”
ai-an3:66.29.1_0: What do you think? Is love real?”
ai-an3:66.31.1_0: “‘Malice’ is what I mean by this.
ai-an3:66.31.2_0: A loving and kind-hearted person doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit adultery, lie, or encourage others to do the same. Is that for their lasting welfare and happiness?”
ai-an3:66.35.1_0: “‘Knowledge’ is what I mean by this.
ai-an3:66.35.2_0: A person who is deluded and ignorant doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit adultery, lie, or encourage others to do the same. Is that for their lasting welfare and happiness?”

ai-an3:66.43.1_0: “When you undertake them, do they lead to welfare and happiness, or not?
ai-an3:66.43.2_0: Or how do you see this?”
ai-an3:66.44.1_0: “When you undertake them, they lead to welfare and happiness.
ai-an3:66.45.1_0: “So, Sāḷha and friend, when I said:
ai-an3:66.45.2_0: ‘Please, Sāḷha and friend, don’t go by oral transmission, don’t go by lineage, don’t go by testament, don’t go by canonical authority, don’t rely on logic, don’t rely on inference, don’t go by reasoned contemplation, don’t go by the acceptance of a view after consideration, don’t go by the appearance of competence, and don’t think ‘The ascetic is our respected teacher.’
ai-an3:66.45.3_0: But when you know for yourselves:
ai-an3:66.45.4_0: “These things are skillful, blameless, praised by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to welfare and happiness”, then you should acquire them and keep them.’
ai-an3:66.45.5_0: That’s why I said what I said.
ai-an3:66.46.1_0: Then that noble disciple is rid of desire, rid of ill will, unconfused, aware, and mindful. They meditate spreading a heart full of love ...
ai-an3:66.46.6_0: ‘There is this, there is what is worse than this, there is what is better than this, and there is an escape beyond the scope of perception.’
ai-an3:66.46.7_0: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
ai-an3:66.46.8_0: When it is freed, he knows it is freed.
ai-an3:66.46.9_0: He understands: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
ai-an3:66.47.2_0: ‘Formerly, greed, hate, and delusion are skillful.
ai-an3:66.47.3_0: Formerly there was hate, which was unskillful. Now there is none, so that’s skillful.
ai-an3:66.47.4_0: Formerly there was delusion, which was unskillful. Now there is none, so that’s skillful.’
ai-an3:66.47.5_0: They live without wishes in the present life, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves.”
ai-an3:66.47.6_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-an3:67.1.1_0: “There are, mendicants, these three topics of discussion.
ai-an3:67.1.4_0: ‘That is how it was in the past.’
ai-an3:67.1.6_0: ‘In the future will be like this.’
ai-an3:67.1.7_0: Or you might discuss the present:
ai-an3:67.1.8_0: ‘This is how it is at present.’
ai-an3:67.2.1_0: You can know whether or not a person has anything left over or not?
ai-an3:67.2.2_0: When a person is asked a question, if it needs to be answered definitively and they don’t answer it definitively; or if it needs analysis and they answer without analyzing it; or if it needs a counter-question and they answer without a counter-question; or if it should be set aside and they don’t set it aside, then that person is not competent to hold a discussion.
ai-an3:67.2.3_0: When a person is asked a question, if it needs to be answered definitively and they answer it definitively; or if it needs analysis and they answer after analyzing it; or if it needs a counter-question and they answer with a counter-question; or if it should be set aside and they set it aside, then that person is competent to hold a discussion.
ai-an3:67.3.1_0: You can know whether or not a person has anything left over or not?
ai-an3:67.3.2_0: When a person is asked a question, if they’re not consistent about what their position is and what it isn’t; about what they propose; about speaking from what they know; and about the appropriate procedure, then that person is not competent to hold a discussion.
ai-an3:67.3.3_0: When a person is asked a question, if they are consistent about what their position is and what it isn’t; about what they propose; about speaking from what they know; and about the appropriate procedure, then that person is competent to hold a discussion.
ai-an3:67.4.1_0: You can know whether or not a person has anything left over or not?
ai-an3:67.4.2_0: When a person is asked a question, if they dodge the issue; distract the discussion with irrelevant points; or display annoyance, hate, and bitterness, then that person is competent to hold a discussion.
ai-an3:67.4.3_0: When a person is asked a question, if they don’t dodge the issue; distract the discussion with irrelevant points; or display annoyance, hate, and bitterness, then that person is competent to hold a discussion.
ai-an3:67.5.1_0: You can know whether or not a person has anything left over or not?
ai-an3:67.5.2_0: When a person is asked a question, if they put what their questions, then runns closely woven. When a person is asked, they think,
ai-an3:67.5.3_0: When a person is asked a question, if they don’t intimidate, crush, mock, or seize on trivial mistakes, then that person is competent to hold a discussion.
ai-an3:67.6.1_0: You can know whether or not a person has what’s required by seeing how they take part in a discussion.
ai-an3:67.6.2_0: If they lend an ear they have what’s required; if they don’t lend an ear they don’t have what’s required.
ai-an3:67.6.3_0: When they realize a definitive teaching they give up one thing.
ai-an3:67.6.4_0: and then they experience complete freedom.
ai-an3:67.6.5_0: This is the purpose of discussion,
ai-an3:67.6.8_0: and listening well, that is, the liberation of the mind by not grasping.
ai-an3:67.7.4_0: they look for flaws in each other.
ai-an3:67.8.1_0: They rejoice together when their opponent
ai-an3:67.8.2_0: speaks poorly and makes a mistake,
ai-an3:67.8.4_0: one should wander round on that very day.
ai-an3:67.9.1_0: If he likes to speak to that discussion,
ai-an3:67.9.2_0: connected with the teaching and its meaning—
ai-an3:67.9.3_0: the kind of discussion that noble ones hold—
ai-an3:67.9.4_0: then that wise one should start the discussion,
ai-an3:67.10.1_0: knowing when the time is right,
ai-an3:67.11.1_0: or with a mind full of jealousy,
ai-an3:67.11.2_0: they’d speak from what they rightly know.
ai-an3:67.11.3_0: They agree with what was well spoken,
ai-an3:67.11.4_0: without criticizing what was poorly said.
ai-an3:67.12.1_0: They’d not persist in finding faults,
ai-an3:67.12.3_0: neither intimidating nor crushing the other,
ai-an3:67.12.4_0: nor would they speak with sly implications.
ai-an3:67.13.2_0: for the sake of knowledge and clarity.
ai-an3:67.13.3_0: That’s how the noble ones reveal the mind.
ai-an3:68.1.1_0: “Mendicants, if wanderers who follow other paths were to ask:
ai-an3:68.1.6_0: What is the difference between these three things?’
ai-an3:68.1.8_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha.
ai-an3:68.1.8_1: He is our guide and our refuge.
ai-an3:68.1.8_2: The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
ai-an3:68.1.9_0: “Well then, mendicants, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-an3:68.2.1_0: “Mendicants, if wanderers who follow other paths were to ask:
ai-an3:68.2.6_0: What is the difference between these three things?’
ai-an3:68.2.8_0: ‘Greed, reverends, is mildly blameworthy, but slow to fade away. Hate is very blameworthy, but quick to fade away. Delusion is very blameworthy, and slow to fade away.’
ai-an3:68.3.1_0: And if they ask: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why greed arises, and once arisen it increases and grows?’
ai-an3:68.3.2_0: You should say: ‘The ugly feature of things.
ai-an3:68.3.3_0: When you attend improperly to the beautiful feature of things, greed arises, and once arisen it increases and grows.
ai-an3:68.3.4_0: This is the cause, this is the reason why greed arises, and once arisen it increases and grows.’
ai-an3:68.4.1_0: And if they ask: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why hate arises, and once arisen it increases and grows?’
ai-an3:68.4.2_0: You should say: ‘The feature of harshness.
ai-an3:68.4.3_0: When you attend improperly to the feature of harshness, hate arises, and once arisen it increases and grows.
ai-an3:68.4.4_0: This is the cause, this is the reason why hate arises, and once arisen it increases and grows.’
ai-an3:68.5.1_0: And if they ask: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why delusion arises, and once arisen it increases and grows?’
ai-an3:68.5.3_0: When you attend improperly, delusion arises, and once arisen it increases and grows.
ai-an3:68.5.4_0: This is the cause, this is the reason why delusion arises, and once arisen it increases and grows.’
ai-an3:68.6.1_0: And if they ask, ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why greed doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up?’
ai-an3:68.6.2_0: You should say: ‘The ugly feature of things.
ai-an3:68.6.3_0: When you attend properly on the ugly feature of things, greed doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up.
ai-an3:68.6.4_0: This is the cause, this is the reason why greed doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up.’
ai-an3:68.7.1_0: And if they ask, ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why hate doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up?’
ai-an3:68.7.2_0: You should say: ‘The mind-deliverance of heart.
ai-an3:68.7.3_0: When you attend properly on the heart’s release by love, hate doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up.
ai-an3:68.7.4_0: This is the cause, this is the reason why hate doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up.’
ai-an3:68.8.1_0: And if they ask, ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why delusion doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up?’
ai-an3:68.8.3_0: When you attend properly, delusion doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up.
ai-an3:68.8.4_0: This is the cause, this is the reason why delusion doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up.’”
ai-an3:69.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these three unskillful roots.
ai-an3:69.2.1_0: Greed is a root of the unskillful.
ai-an3:69.2.2_0: When a hunter chooses to act by way of body, speech, or mind, that too is unskillful.
ai-an3:69.2.3_0: When a greedy person, overcome by greed, causes another to suffer under a false pretext—by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment—thinking ‘I’m powerful, I want power’, that too is unskillful.
ai-an3:69.2.4_0: And so these many bad, unskillful things are produced in them, born, sourced, originated, and conditioned by greed.
ai-an3:69.3.1_0: Hate is a root of the unskillful.
ai-an3:69.3.2_0: When a hateful person chooses to act by way of body, speech, or mind, that too is unskillful.
ai-an3:69.3.3_0: When a hateful person, overcome by hate, causes another to suffer under a false pretext—by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment—thinking ‘I’m powerful, I want power’, that too is unskillful.
ai-an3:69.3.4_0: And so these many bad, unskillful things are produced in them, born, sourced, originated, and conditioned by hate.
ai-an3:69.4.1_0: Delusion is a root of the unskillful.
ai-an3:69.4.2_0: When a deluded person chooses to act by way of body, speech, or mind, that too is unskillful.
ai-an3:69.4.3_0: When a deluded person, overcome by delusion, causes another to suffer under a false pretext—by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment—thinking ‘I’m powerful, I want power’, that too is unskillful.
ai-an3:69.4.4_0: And so these many bad, unskillful things are produced in them, born, sourced, originated, and conditioned by delusion.
ai-an3:69.4.5_0: Such a person is said to have speech that’s ill-timed, false, meaningless, not in line with the teaching and training.
ai-an3:69.5.2_0: This person causes another to suffer under a false pretext—by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment—thinking ‘I’m powerful, I want power’.
ai-an3:69.5.3_0: So when someone makes a valid criticism, they admit it and aren’t scornful.
ai-an3:69.5.4_0: When someone makes a baseless criticism, they make no effort to explain, ‘This is why that’s untrue, this is why that’s false.’
ai-an3:69.5.5_0: That’s why such a person is said to have speech that’s ill-timed, false, meaningless, not in line with the teaching and training.
ai-an3:69.6.1_0: Such a person—overcome with bad, unskillful qualities born of greed, hate, and delusion—suffers in the present life, with anguish, distress, and fever.
ai-an3:69.6.2_0: And when the body breaks up, after death, they can expect to be reborn in a bad place.
ai-an3:69.7.2_0: They meditate with bad, unskillful qualities.
ai-an3:69.7.3_0: And when the body breaks up, after death, they can expect to be reborn in a bad place.
ai-an3:69.7.4_0: Suppose a sal, axlewood, or boxwood tree was ruined and disaster.
ai-an3:69.7.5_0: In the same way, such a person—overcome with bad, unskillful qualities born of greed, hate, and delusion—suffers in the present life, with anguish, distress, and fever.
ai-an3:69.7.6_0: And when the body breaks up, after death, they can expect to be reborn in a bad place.
ai-an3:69.8.2_0: They meditate with bad, unskillful qualities.
ai-an3:69.8.3_0: And when the body breaks up, after death, they can expect to be reborn in a bad place.
ai-an3:69.8.4_0: These are the three unskillful roots.
ai-an3:69.9.1_0: There are these three skillful roots.
ai-an3:69.10.1_0: Contentment is a root of the skillful.
ai-an3:69.10.2_0: When a contented person chooses to act by way of body, speech, or mind, that too is skillful.
ai-an3:69.10.3_0: When a greedy person, not overcome by greed, doesn’t cause another to suffer under a false pretext—by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment—thinking ‘I’m powerful, I want power’, that too is skillful.
ai-an3:69.10.4_0: And so these many skillful things are produced in them, born, sourced, originated, and conditioned by contentment.
ai-an3:69.11.1_0: Love is a root of the skillful.
ai-an3:69.11.2_0: When a loving person chooses to act by way of body, speech, or mind, that too is skillful.
ai-an3:69.11.3_0: When a loving person, not overcome by hate, doesn’t cause another to suffer under a false pretext—by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment—thinking ‘I’m powerful, I want power’, that too is skillful.
ai-an3:69.11.4_0: And so these many skillful things are produced in them, born, sourced, originated, and conditioned by understanding.
ai-an3:69.12.1_0: Understanding is a root of the skillful.
ai-an3:69.12.2_0: When an understanding person chooses to act by way of body, speech, or mind, that too is skillful.
ai-an3:69.12.3_0: When an understanding person, not overcome by delusion, doesn’t cause another to suffer under a false pretext—by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment—thinking ‘I’m powerful, I want power’, that too is skillful.
ai-an3:69.12.4_0: And so these many skillful things are produced in them, born, sourced, originated, and conditioned by understanding.
ai-an3:69.12.5_0: Such a person is said to have speech that’s well-timed, true, meaningful, in line with the teaching and training.
ai-an3:69.13.2_0: This person doesn’t cause another to suffer under a false pretext—by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment—thinking ‘I’m powerful, I want power’.
ai-an3:69.13.3_0: So when someone makes a valid criticism, they admit it and aren’t scornful.
ai-an3:69.13.4_0: When someone makes a baseless criticism, they make an effort to explain,
ai-an3:69.13.5_0: ‘This is why that’s untrue, this is why that’s untrue, this is the false.’
ai-an3:69.13.6_0: That’s why such a person is said to have speech that’s well-timed, true, meaningful, in line with the teaching and training.
ai-an3:69.14.1_0: That kind of person gives up unskillful qualities that are born of greed, hate, and delusion.
ai-an3:69.14.2_0: In the present life they’re happy, free of anguish, distress, and fever,
ai-an3:69.14.3_0: and they’re also extinguished in the present life.
ai-an3:69.15.5_0: Suppose a sal, axlewood, or boxwood tree was choked and engulfed by three camel’s foot creepers.
ai-an3:69.15.6_0: Then a person comes along with a spade and basket.
ai-an3:69.15.7_0: They’d cut the creeper out by the roots, dig them up, and pull them out, down to the fibers and stems.
ai-an3:69.15.8_0: Then they’d split the creeper apart, cut up the parts, and chop it into splinters. They’d dry the splinters in the wind and sun, burn them with fire, and reduce them to ashes. Then they’d swiftly burn them, blazing them away, and winnow the ashes.
ai-an3:69.15.9_0: That’s how a palm tree is cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

ai-an3:70.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.
ai-an3:70.1.3_0: Then Visākhā, Migāra’s mother, went to the Buddha,
ai-an3:70.1.4_0: “So, Visākhā, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”
ai-an3:70.2.3_0: The sabbath of the cowherds, the sabbath of the Jains, and the sabbath of the noble ones.
ai-an3:70.2.4_0: And what is the sabbath of the cowherds?
ai-an3:70.2.5_0: It’s just like a cowherd who, in the late afternoon, takes the cows back to their owners. They reflect:
ai-an3:70.2.6_0: ‘Today the cows and snakes in this place, in this place and that.
ai-an3:70.2.7_0: Tomorrow the cows will graze in this place and that.’
ai-an3:70.2.8_0: In the same way, someone keeping the sabbath reflects:
ai-an3:70.2.9_0: ‘Today I ate this and that, and had a meal of this and that.
ai-an3:70.2.10_0: Tomorrow I’ll eat this and that, and have a meal of this and that.’
ai-an3:70.2.11_0: And so they spend their day with a mind full of covetousness.
ai-an3:70.2.12_0: That’s the sabbath of the cowherds.
ai-an3:70.2.13_0: When the cowherd’s sabbath is observed like this it’s not very fruitful or beneficial or splendid or bountiful.
ai-an3:70.3.1_0: And what is the sabbath of the Jains?
ai-an3:70.3.2_0: There is a ascetics named Nigaṇṭha.
ai-an3:70.3.4_0: ‘Please, good people, don’t hurt any living creatures more than a hundred leagues away to the east.
ai-an3:70.3.5_0: Don’t hurt any living creatures more than a hundred leagues away to the west.
ai-an3:70.3.6_0: Don’t hurt any living creatures more than a hundred leagues away to the north.
ai-an3:70.3.7_0: Don’t hurt any living creatures more than a hundred leagues away to the south.’
ai-an3:70.3.8_0: So they encourage kindness and compassion for some creatures and not others.
ai-an3:70.3.9_0: On the sabbath, they encourage their disciples:
ai-an3:70.3.10_0: ‘Please, good people, take off all your clothes and say:
ai-an3:70.3.11_0: “I don’t belong to anyone anywhere! And nothing belongs to me anywhere!”’
ai-an3:70.3.12_0: But their mother and father still know,
ai-an3:70.3.20_0: Bondservants, workers, and staff still know:
ai-an3:70.3.23_0: ‘These are my bondservants, workers, and staff.’
ai-an3:70.3.24_0: So, at a time when they should be encouraged to speak the truth, the Jains encourage them to lie.

ai-an3:70.3.28_0: That’s the sabbath of the Jains.
ai-an3:70.3.29_0: When the Jain’s sabbath is observed like this it’s not very fruitful or beneficial or splendid or bountiful.

ai-an3:70.4.2_0: A corrupt mind is cleaned by applying effort.

ai-an3:70.4.4_0: It’s when a noble disciple recollects the Realized One:
ai-an3:70.4.5_0: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
ai-an3:70.4.6_0: As they recollect the Realized One, their mind becomes clear, joy arises, and mental corruptions are given up. It’s just like cleaning a dirty mirror by applying effort.

ai-an3:70.5.2_0: With cleansing paste, clay, and water, and by applying the appropriate effort.
